title: Miss O'Dell: My Hard Days and Long Nights with The Beatles,The Stones, Bob Dylan, Eric Clapton, and the Women They Loved
description: pChris O'Dell wasn't famous. She wasn't even almost famous. But she was there.pShe was in the studio when the Beatles recorded IThe White Album/I, IAbbey Road/I, and ILet It Be/I, and when Paul recorded "Hey Jude," she sang in the chorus.pShe was at Ringo's kitchen table when George Harrison said, "You know, Ringo, I'm in love with your wife," and Ringo replied, "Better you than someone we don't know."pShe typed the lyrics to George Harrison's IAll Things Must Pass/I. She lived with George and Pattie Boyd at Friar Park, developed a crush on Eric Clapton, and unwittingly got involved in the famous love story between Eric and Pattie.pShe's the subject of Leon Russell's "Pisces Apple Lady," a song he wrote to woo her. Other rock legends with whom she was intimate include Ringo, Mick Jagger, and Bob Dylan.pShe worked with the Rolling Stones as their personal assistant on their infamous 1972 tour and did a drug run for Keith Richards.pShe's "the woman down the hall" in Joni Mitchell's song "Coyote" about a love triangle on Bob Dylan's Rolling Thunder Revue tour. She's the "mystery woman" pictured on the back of the Rolling Stones album IExile on Main Street/I. She's the "Miss O'Dell" of George Harrison's song about her.pJam-packed with intimate anecdotes, IMiss O'Dell/I is a backstage pass to some of the most momentous events in rock history.
author: Chris O'Dell
